content:
This is not a clearly defined puzzle.

I got 100% in reverse mode by solving using complex rules that aren't the same as your solution but luckily you don't have any tests that differentiate them.

My solution was to assume that there was either one odd number or one even number in the array and print whichever was the minority, but if there are no odd numbers then print 0.

If you'd had a test where there were multiple odd numbers in the array then I would've been able to rule my logic out, but you never have a case where there are more than 1 odd numbers in the array...

n = gets.to_i
a = gets.split.map &:to_i
o=a.select(&:odd?)
e =a.select(&:even?)
puts o.empty?? 0 : e.empty?? o : [o,e].min_by(&:size)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It fits the reverse mode requirements and it's funny

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice task. The title is a hint. =)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: good idea for a clash
The title isn't shown during a clash ðŸ˜‰

Except the underlying constraint is that there is always exactly one odd number and zero or more even numbers in the input, so I do not wish to add any test with multiple odd numbers (or none).

Reverse is a speed contest, and having acting on a more complex interpretation of the puzzle lose you the puzzle because you didn't observe enough and missed the simpler interpretation is actually a very interesting outcome I didn't foresee. It encourages you to aim at simpler interpretations, keeping it simple, which is a really useful skill in real life. :-)
